required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 10, 2022
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Tau Pet Imaging in the Aging Brain Cohort Dedicated to Diversity Study
clinical_study.official_title: Tau Pet Imaging in the Aging Brain Cohort Dedicated to Diversity Study

brief_summary.textblock: We will conduct a Tau PET scan in cognitively normal older adults, enrolled in the Aging Brain Cohort Dedicated to Diversity Study (ABCD2-Tau) study at the University of Pennsylvania's Penn Memory Center/Alzheimer's Disease Core Center (PMC/ADC).Study duration will generally be a one-day study visit for PET imaging, but all subjects will be followed annually as part of their participation in the ABCD2 study. Findings from this study will likely provide insight into the mechanisms and distinctions of age-related cognitive decline and that of preclinical Alzheimer's Disease.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: This is a cross-sectional study using the radiotracer 18F-Flortaucipir to determine the relationship of tau pathology to both cross-sectional and longitudinal clinical and biomarker data of ABCD2 cohort participants who are Cognitively Normal. All subjects will already be part of the longitudinal cohort study, known as the "ABCD2" cohort, of the PMC/ADC. For the current protocol, participants will provide informed consent before beginning any study procedures. After screening assessments, participants will undergo PET/CT scan imaging with 18F-Flortaucipir.

primary_outcome.measure: Uptake of [18F]AV-1451 in the medial temporal lobe
primary_outcome.description: A quantitative measurement of [18F]AV-1451(standardized value uptake ratio - SUVR) within the medial temporal lobe (MTL).from PET/CT

primary_outcome.measure: Volume of medial temporal lobe subregion
primary_outcome.description: A quantitative measurement of volume (milimeters - mm) of medial temporal lobe (MTL) subregion from a high resolution MRI.

primary_outcome.measure: Thickness of medial temporal lobe subregion
primary_outcome.description: A quantitative measurement of thickness (milimeters - mm) of medial temporal lobe (MTL) subregion from a high resolution MRI.

intervention.description: [18F]AV-1451 has been developed as a positron emitting radiopharmaceutical for in vivo imaging of tau protein aggregates.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Males and females African Americans â‰¥ 65 years of age.
2. Part of the ABCD2 longitudinal cohort, protocol 844047, of the PMC/ADCC with consensus conference designation of normal cognition.
3. ABCD2 longitudinal visit must be completed or scheduled to be completed within 180 days prior to the [18F]AV-1451 TAU PET scan.
4. A brain MRI must be performed within 180 days prior to their study [18F]AV-1451 TAU PET scan date and be deemed of adequate quality that the scan may be used for study analysis, including 3T high-resolution imaging of medial temporal lobe structures.
5. An amyloid PET scan completed or scheduled within 180 days of their study [18F]AV-1451
6. Women must be post-menopausal or surgically sterile.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Have any medical or psychiatric conditions that, in the opinion of the investigator, would compromise the subject's safety or successful participation in the study, including major depression and prior head trauma.
2. Have evidence of structural abnormalities such as major stroke or mass on MRI that is likely to interfere with analysis of the PET scan.
3. Inability to tolerate or contraindication to imaging procedures in the opinion of an investigator or treating physician.
4. Have a history of significant ongoing alcohol or substance abuse or dependence based on self-report.
5. Women of child bearing potential
- The inclusion / exclusion criteria will be ascertained through self-report in conjunction with any medical history available through the participant's medical or research records (EPIC or the ADC database)*

facility.name: Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania - Penn Memory Center
